Submarine mass movements on glaciated and non-glaciated European
continental margins: A review of triggering mechanisms
and preconditions to failure
D. Leynaud a,*, J. Mienert a, M. Vanneste b

a Department of Geology, University of Tromsø, Dramsveien 201, N-9037 Tromsø, Norway
b International Centre of Geohazards and NGI, Oslo, Norway

Article history:
Received 5 September 2006
Received in revised form 6 December 2007
Accepted 7 February 2008
Available online 19 July 2008

In this paper we present an overview of the major triggering mechanisms and preconditions for slope
failure on the European continental margins, a vast area in which the dominant factors on sedimentation
and erosional processes vary both spatially and temporally. Therefore, we have collated and integrated
new as well as published data for both the formerly glaciated and non-glaciated areas of this highly
dynamic margin for a time period mainly from the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) to the present. Mass
transport type is predominantly translational sliding on the high-latitude continental margins (north of
52N), whereas turbidites dominate on lower latitudes. This is partly related to the average slope of the
respective continental margin segments and differences in both sediment types and soil properties.
Additionally, on low latitudes, submarine slope failures mainly occurred during glacial conditions with
low sea level, whereas on high latitudes, they occur during the relatively fast transition from glacial to
interglacial conditions (i.e. during periods of sea level rise). The largest submarine slides (e.g. Storegga,
Trænadjupet, Andøya) on the glaciated Norwegian margin occurred during the Holocene, a time of rapid
ice sheet decay, continental uplift and increased seismic activity, one of the most important triggering
mechanisms for large failures during deglaciation processes. Preconditioning factors such as weak layers
related to contourite drifts and rapid loading by glacial sediments may enhance strain localization and
creep processes on the slope.

1. Introduction

The aim of this study is to present and discuss the large variety of
mass wasting processes on glaciated and non-glaciated continental
margins of the NE-Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Seas in rela-
tion to seismic hazards, sediment properties, and sea level changes.
The assessment of today’s submarine continental slope stability
requires an understanding of what has caused submarine slope
failures in the past. Knowledge of preconditions of sediments to fail
and their
triggering
mechanisms has
improved signiﬁcantly
following extensive studies conducted throughout the world.
Particularly the multidisciplinary investigations and interactions
between academia and industry in studying the giant Storegga
Slide complex of the mid-Norwegian margin have revealed new
insights into the occurrence and dynamics of mass wasting in

relation to sedimentation and oceanographic processes, glacial
history and seismicity, which together form a key study for slope
failure on (formerly) glaciated margins (e.g. Mienert, 2004; Bryn
et al., 2005a; Solheim et al., 2005a, b). Potential preconditions to
failure exist in the form of weak sediment layers, and they have
been used to explain the architecture of the Storegga Slide (Bryn
et al., 2003). However, the absence of other large (regional) scale
slope failures in similar geological settings is difﬁcult to under-
stand, and we need to shed more light on such complex, interacting
processes.
In order to gather more information about the key parameters
controlling sediment instabilities on continental margins, it is
essential to study both the spatial distribution and the frequency of
submarine slides (e.g., McAdoo et al., 2000;Canals et al., 2004b;
Mienert, 2004). Instabilities on continental margins are of interest
not only for the understanding of sedimentary processes building
or removing strata but also for estimatingdand ultimately elimi-
natingdrisks related to failure impacts on offshore infrastructure
and coastal communities (e.g. tsunami generation). A variety of
mass wasting types and processes involving signiﬁcantly different
volumes from less than 1 km3 to several 1000 km3 are commonly

observed on both the active (Mediterranean) and passive (NE-
Atlantic) margins (Canals et al., 2004b). Mega-size (sediment
volume >1000 km3) sediment slides appear to be concentrated on
the formerly glaciated margins of the NE-Atlantic, extending over
several hundreds of km on the mid-Norwegian margin (e.g. the
Storegga Slide, Haﬂidason et al., 2004) and the Arctic margin north
of Svalbard (Vanneste et al., 2006; Winklemann et al., 2006). One of
the characteristics and development mechanism for slope failure
on glaciated margins is retrogressive sliding; however, one should
not ignore (glacial and non-glacial) debris ﬂows, turbidites and
megaturbidites. All these speciﬁc sedimentary processes affect the
continental margin morphology and sub-seaﬂoor character from
the shelf break and upper slope to the deep ocean basins. These
processes lead to a diversity of seismic signatures from chaotic
sediment depocentres to well-stratiﬁed layers, sedimentary scarps
and sediment pressure ridges, which are in turn partly draped or
inﬁlled by contourite drifts, related to well-established oceano-
graphic circulation patterns (e.g. Laberg and Vorren, 2003a; Canals
et al., 2004a; Haﬂidason et al., 2004; Solheim et al., 2005a).
A variety of mechanisms can initiate submarine mass movement
(Sultan et al., 2004a). For example, the rapid deformation of sedi-
ments affecting the stress–strain relationship could lead to
sediment failure, whereas a more progressive deformation of
sediments may allow a change in soil properties and shear strength
leading to strain softening and creeping. Among the potential
triggers and destabilization processes, the most relevant are high
sedimentation rates, climatically-controlled alternations in sedi-
mentation, gas hydrate dissociation in the sediment’s pore space,
diapirism, uplift and earthquakes, which would all lead to excess
pore pressure development and consequently reduction of shear
strength (Bryn et al., 2005a).
Using a recent compilation of submarine mass movements on
European continental margins, we try to highlight their genesis

mechanisms at a large-scale (Atlantic and Mediterranean) to
emphasize similarities between mass wasting events occurring in
closed areas and thus propose some models regarding likely
recurrent processes at regional scales.
2. Geological settings

For simpliﬁcation, we have split up the discussion on Europe’s
margins in two distinct margin types (Tables 1–3; Fig. 1) being:

(1) the formerly glaciated margin north of 52N, sculpted by
massive mass wasting features including mega-scale slides and
glacigenic debris ﬂows, and
(2) non-glaciated margin south of 52N, where megaturbidites and
large-scale debris ﬂows dominate.

The non-glaciated margin is further subdivided. The ﬁrst area lies
between 52N and 35N and the margin morphology shows
numerous canyon incisions. The second area lies south of 35N with
a multitude of large-scale debris ﬂows and mega-turbidites. The
third area corresponds to the Mediterranean Sea which is made up of
both active and passive margin segments (e.g. Hieke, 2000), with
slumps, slides, debris ﬂows and megaturbidites (Rothwell et al.,1998,
2000; Hieke, 2000; Canals et al., 2004b). The three margin types
proposed by Weaver et al. (2000) are also mentioned in Table 1.
2.1. Glaciated-margin north of 52N

The formerly glaciated margin north of 52N, and especially the
Norwegian–Barents–Svalbard margin, is characterized by major
cross-shelf troughs with extensive trough–mouth fan systems that
have developed at their mouth on the upper continental slope (e.g.
Vorren et al., 2003). These trough–mouth fan systems consist of

stacked debris lobes and develop beyond the shelf break, in front of
fast ﬂowing ice streams where gravity-controlled mass ﬂows (i.e.
debris ﬂows, turbidity currents) of sediments takes place during
glacial times. Taylor et al. (2002) estimated that, on the Norwegian
Sea margin, approximately 75% of sediment deposited in the
deeper basins are provided by debris ﬂows. During interglacial
times, contour currents driven by global thermohaline circulation
have built a number of major sediment drifts (Laberg and Vorren,
2003b). These contourite drifts have been identiﬁed offshore Nor-
way (Nyk drift, Dahlgren et al., 2002; Lofoten drift, Laberg and
Vorren, 2003b), NW of Ireland (Feni drift, Haas et al., 2003) and
offshore Shetlands and Faeroe (Van Weering et al., 1998a). Whereas
contourite drifts in deep-sea basins south of 60N are related to the
circulation of deep-water masses (Mienert et al., 1994), drifts
further north of 60N on the Norwegian margin appear related to
intermediate water masses (Laberg and Vorren, 2004). During
glacial times, sedimentation rates on glaciated margins were high
(several 10 m/kyr) and closely related to the location and dynamics
of former ice streams (Sejrup et al., 2004). The last major phase of
large-scale submarine sliding occurred during the Holocene,
particularly offshore Norway (Storegga Slide, Trænadjupet Slide),
where the geological history reveals long-term instability over the
last 500 ka (Evans et al., 1996; Bryn et al, 2003; Haﬂidason et al.,
2004; Solheim et al., 2005a).
2.2. Non-glaciated margin South of 52N

2.2.1. Non-glaciated Atlantic margin between 35 and 52N
Between 35N and 52N, numerous submarine canyons incise
the continental slope, thereby creating pathways for sediment
transfer from the shelf break to the abyssal plains. The areas with

canyons often have steep open slopes from 4 to 9. The shelf width
and thereby the distance to the sediment source area vary
considerably. For example, the Porcupine margin (offshore Irish
coast, approximately 52N) and the Armorican margin (offshore
French coast, 46N) including the Celtic margin (48N) are char-
acterised by a relatively wide shelf (w150 km) which contrasts
with the narrower shelf of the Iberian margin (from <10 km to
60 km).
Sedimentation in the northern areas has been inﬂuenced by
deglaciation and melt-water processes, but large-scale mass
movements are scarce on this part of the margin (Weaver et al.,
2000). Both the continental slope and rise are steep and narrow
thus shortening the transport pathway from the shelf and upper
slope to the abyssal plain.
During glacial times and low sea levels, terrigenous sediment
was delivered either directly to the canyon heads or at relatively
short distances from the latter, which suggest higher transport
activity within the canyons during these periods. Submarine fans
developed at the outlet of the canyons and the wide-spread
deposition from turbidity currents contributed to build-out the
abyssal plains (Weaver et al., 2000). There are also important
contourite systems on the non-glaciated margins, as for example in
the Gulf of Cadiz and several sectors of the Mediterranean Sea
(Rebesco and Stow, 2002).

2.2.2. Non-glaciated Atlantic margin south of 35N
South of 35N sediment accumulation on the continental
margin is driven by coastal upwelling creating sediments with
elevated biogenic content, while ﬂuvial inputs remain apparently
low. There is evidence of large-scale mass wasting of these sedi-
ments in the form of debris ﬂows and turbidity currents on time

scales of several million years (Weaver et al., 2000). The high
organic content of mega-turbidites on the Madeira Abyssal Plain
indicates that unstable sediments have been deposited on the
upper slope at coastal upwelling regions, which have high sedi-
mentation rates on the order of 15 cm/ka (Weaver et al., 2000).
Volcanic islands also contribute to the large-scale mass-movement
sediment budget in this area. (Masson et al., 1997; Krastel et al.,
2003). It is also worth noting that the continental slope on the NW-
African continental margin has generally low dip angles, around 0.5
–2, and a narrow shelf (shelf similar to the Iberian margin).

2.2.3. Non-glaciated margins of the Mediterranean Sea
The Mediterranean margins are mainly controlled by ﬂuvial
input (Ebro, Rhoˆne, Po, Nile; e.g. Berne´ and Satra, 2002; Casas et al.,
2003; Ambla`s et al., 2004; Berne´ et al., 2004; Canals et al., 2004a;
Cattaneo et al., 2004; Trincardi et al., 2004). Submarine canyons
incise the continental slopes both in the occidental part (e.g. Gulf of
Lions, NW-Mediterranean Sea) and in the oriental part (e.g. Gulf of
Salum, west of the Nile delta). Compared to the NE-Atlantic
continental margin, the shelf of the Mediterranean Seas is nearly
absent in many areas whereas the continental slope is rather steep
but laterally variable. The slope dips between 1.6 and 3.8 (Gulf of
Lion; Berne´ and Satra, 2002) or between 5 and 6 (Var Continental
Slope;Mulder et al., 1998), and becomes locally very steep (15–20

slope (Urgeles et al., 2005). In some areas, as Ebro, Gulf of Lyons (off
Rhone) and Adriatic Sea the width of the shelf becomes important.
Megaturbidites of Pleistocene age are well-documented from the
Balearic and Herodotus abyssal plains (Rothwell et al., 1998, 2000).
However, no mega-scale submarine sliding, with dimensions
similar to those on the NE-Atlantic margin has been observed in the
Mediterranean Seas. Since the eastern Mediterranean Sea corre-
sponds to an active continental margin, the role of seismic activity
in creating mass movements should be carefully considered.
3. Triggering mechanisms and preconditions to failure
3.1. Glaciated margins

A list of documented submarine slope failures on the European
glaciated margin north of 52N is listed in Table 2. This table
provides the database to assess the main parameters controlling
slope failures on such margins. As mentioned above, the formerly
glaciated margins are dominated by high sedimentation rates
(1–40 m/kyr) related to the presence or proximity of an ice sheet
and ice stream dynamics on the continental shelf during glacial
times (e.g. Sejrup et al., 2004). The continental margins are also
characterized by subsidence or uplift processes due to the existence
or absence of ice sheets (Bungum et al., 2005). The margin is also
swept by contour currents (Laberg and Vorren, 2004).

3.1.1. Triggering mechanisms: Seismic activity and seismic loading
Seismic hazards offshore Fennoscandinavia (Fig. 1) might be
underestimated considering the more pronounced seismic activity
which likely followed the isostatic rebound from 10 ka to the
present (Bryn et al., 2003; Bungum et al., 2005), seismic activity
which was not observed to such a degree during the very recent
period. Earthquake-induced excess pore pressure generation can
lead to the liquefaction of coarse-grained, cohesionless soils.
Therefore, a key question addresses the location, magnitude and
frequency of earthquakes on these margins (Fig. 1), factors which
can only be inferred from historical records or modelling scenarios
for past times; this implies that uncertainty remains when relating
the occurrence of certain slope failures with earthquakes. Fig. 1
shows the location of submarine slides on the formerly glaciated
and non-glaciated European Margin (including NW Africa) as well
as the observed seismic accelerations today. The highest accelera-
tions occur in the eastern Mediterranean from where it decreases
towards the west. The NE Atlantic margins where mega-scale
sliding has occurred during the Holocene correspond to a region
with low seismic accelerations background. In general, one
assumes that earthquakes are among the most obvious and best
known triggering mechanisms for submarine slides (Piper et al.,
1988). Depending on the direction of the earthquake-generated
seismic waves, the seismic acceleration can increase the soil mass
effect downslope and thus promote slope instability.
However, another form of seismicity should be considered when
discussing formerly glaciated margins, i.e. the seismicity related to
glacio-isostatic processes. According to Siegert and Dowdeswell
(2004), the Eurasian ice sheet reached its maximum volume of
roughly 5.5  106 km3 around 16 ka. After the deglaciation, isostatic
uplift has been estimated in the Barents Sea around 100 m/kyr at
9 ka and for Eastern Scandinavia around 300 m/kyr between 11 ka
and 9 ka (Bungum et al., 2005). These authors proposed a fast uplift
between 10 and 8 ka followed by a slower uplift between 7 and
2 ka. They also suggest that, while glacial isostatic adjustment and
seismicity are related, the relationship is ambiguous. However, an
intensiﬁed high seismicity period with the occurrence of several M
7þ earthquakes is documented at around 10 ka. Dating of fault
activity in northern Fennoscandia provide 8200  250 a for the
Parve fault (estimated moment magnitude M of 8.1; single event)

and 9300 a for the Masi fault (estimated moment magnitude M of
7.7; single event; Bungum and Lindholm,1996). These observations
clearly point towards higher frequency of seismic hazards in this
area during the early Holocene. Although mega-scale submarine
landslides like the Storegga Slide and the Trænadjupet Slide are
located near transform zones (Holler, 1986), these primary struc-
tural elements have most likely not been reactivated during
isostatic uplift (Bungum et al., 2005), and thus, have not played
a major role in submarine slope failure. However, Bryn et al. (2003)
considered that postglacial earthquake activity due to glacio-
isostatic rebound is the most likely trigger for the Storegga slide.
Another area of documented seismic activity lies on the UK margin
(Fig. 1, No. 15). Two recent low-magnitude seismic events (M ¼ 3.3
and M ¼ 3.1) have been localized in the vicinity of the Peach slide,
which is of Pleistocene age (Long and Holmes, 2001), which may
suggest a long term seismic potential for destabilizing sediments in
this area.
For the Storegga slide, ﬁnite element simulation indicates that
a strong earthquake (magnitude around 6.5–7.0) is a potential
trigger for slope failures down to a subsurface depth of only 30 m
and suggests that another process preconditioning to failure (i.e.
‘‘slide-prone’’ layer development) is needed for sediment to fail in
the deeper sub surface (Leynaud et al., 2004).

3.1.1.1. Shear strength degradation with seismic loading. The degra-
dation of shear strength due to cyclic loading can play a major role
in undermining the stability of the slope. During this cyclic loading,
accumulated deformations lead to a reduction of the soil resistance.
Nadim et al. (1996) performed cyclic tests (direct simple shear) on
Finneidfjord (Norway) soft clays and concluded that: (1) cyclic
shear strength under earthquake loading was greater than static
shear strength (60–80%), (2) a signiﬁcant reduction of static shear
strength could be observed if large cyclic shear strains (higher than
6–8%) were experienced during earthquakes, leading to creep
displacement
after
the
cyclic
loading.
However,
the
post-
earthquake, post-creep static shear strength reduction was around
25%. Based on these results, they concluded that this was not
enough to drastically affect the stability of this speciﬁc area.

Kramer (1996) considered that slope stability is strongly inﬂu-
enced by the strength resulting from large strains. Two types of
strength should be considered: (1) the cyclic strength (during cyclic
loading) that depends on both average shear stress and cyclic shear
stress, and (2) the post-earthquake undrained shear strength that
will be identical to the static case considering that no structural
change takes place despite excess pore pressure development.
However, the strength after cyclic loading can be reduced to about
40% with a peak cyclic strain equal to 75% of the failure strain in
a static test. Hence, even a low cyclic strain can lead to a reduced
post-earthquake
strength
and
consequent
slope
failure.
The
dynamic behaviour (cumulative strain with repetitive cycles) can
also reduce the soil’s shear resistance in non-cohesive sediments,
and an earthquake-induced excess pore pressure generation can
result in the liquefaction of sediments (Leynaud et al., 2004; Sultan
et al., 2004a).

3.1.2. Preconditions to failure
3.1.2.1. High sedimentation rates. High sedimentation rates on the
continental slope during ice ages (Sejrup et al., 2004) are another
important factor in submarine slope stability assessment. The
Trænadjupet and Storegga slide areas (Fig. 1, Tables 2 and 3) are
characterized by the modest sedimentation rates (less than
1 m/kyr) during interglacials alternated with signiﬁcantly higher
sedimentation rates (several tens of meters per kyr) at the end of
each glacial period. At the Trænadjupet Slide, Laberg et al. (2002b)
estimated an average rate of 65 m/kyr for the glacigenic sediments
(older than 15.51 ka) while for the Storegga slide Hjelstuen et al.

(2004) proposed a maximum of 36 m/ka (15.7–15.0 ka) at the
northern boundary of the slide complex (Helland Hansen area).
This rate could be even higher further south, in the vicinity of the
Norwegian
Channel,
which
represents
the
main
ice-stream
drainage pathway during peak glaciations (Bryn et al., 2003;
Siegert
and
Dowdeswell,
2004).
Bryn
et
al.
(2003,
2005a)
concluded for the Storegga slide area that unfavourable shear
stress and excess pore pressure existed in the marine contouritic
clay units following their rapid burial by thick deposits of glacial
clays. Taylor et al. (2002) report that high Late Weichselian
ice-sheet sediment ﬂuxes were mainly concentrated in the
trough–mouth fans deposited in front of cross-shelf troughs. Using
the ice-sheet retreat proposed by Siegert and Dowdeswell (2004);
(LGM, 15 ka and 11 ka ice margin), one observes that the locations
of mega-scale slides correspond approximately to the ice sheet
limit at the LGM (Fig. 2). Thus, rapid changes in sedimentation
rates could have been responsible for excess pore pressure build
up in the Storrega area (e.g. Leynaud et al., 2007). Since several
pre-Holocene slides have been observed in the surrounding area
of the Storegga Slide (i.e. Tampen Slide, Møre Slide, S Slide, W
Slide, R Slide) there is ample evidence that glacial deposits based
on the approximately 100 kyr Milankovitch cycle (Solheim et al.,
2005a) have had major effects on slope stability (Fig. 3); the upper
limit of the slide area on the sketch corresponds to the occurrence
time of the slide while the lower limit represents the oldest glide
plane involved in the slide. A 100 kyr cycle is observed from the
succession of slide occurrences up to 0.5 Ma (Storegga, Tampen,
Slides R and Sklinadjupet, Møre, Slide S) as well as the role of
successive interglacial deposits as glide planes (INO3, TNR, TNS).

names in the right part of the sketch (INO3, INO4, etc.) refers to the seismic horizons corresponding to the repetitive glide planes in the area (bottom boundary) and are also used to
deﬁne the timing of the slides occurrence (upper boundary).

3.1.2.2. Excess pore pressure development
3.1.2.2.1. Before complete consolidation. Rapid overloading of
ﬁne-grained
sediments could generate excess pore pressure
depending on permeability and water content in the sediment. As
the undrained shear strength of the sediment during the consoli-
dation process depends on the excess pore pressure dissipation, the
change in strength with time needs to be modelled. A high excess
pore pressure developing in the soil during consolidation will
impede the natural increase of effective stress with sediment
burial. Depending on the excess pore pressure dissipation, the
undrained shear strength might remain low.
3.1.2.2.2. After complete consolidation. When the sediment is
initially fully consolidated (i.e. complete dissipation of excess pore
pressure), a cyclic loading such as earthquake ground motion or gas
accumulation can generate excess pore pressure in the sediment
pores. The undrained shear strength is only affected by excess pore
pressure generation if liquefaction occurs, or by cyclic loading
leading to a possible degradation of shear strength. Therefore, the
drained shear strength should be considered to ensure whether or
not excess pore pressure conditions can result in slope failure.

Bryn et al. (2003) proposed a model in which a lateral transfer of
excess pore pressure from high permeability layers (oozes of the
Brygge Formation; south of the Storegga Slide) to low permeability
sediments (clays of the Naust Formation; north of the Storegga
Slide) takes place.

3.1.2.3. Liquefaction of soils. Liquefaction of cohesionless soils is
one process enhancing the likelihood of slope failures to occur.
Liquefaction means that the excess pore pressure in sandy sedi-
ments equals more or less the initial vertical effective stress
(vertical effective stress becoming zero) and thus the sediment
shear strength approaches null values (in other words, the sedi-
ment behaves as a liquid). A sign of possible predisposing factor for
a slope to fail was observed at the Afen slide (Fig. 1, No 13; Table 2).
Wilson et al. (2003) observed the presence of well-sorted sands in
debris lobes pointing towards the existence of formerly liqueﬁed
layers. Contouritic sediments can act as weak layers considering
their lower shear strength or higher sensitivity (Laberg et al., 2003),
and they provide potential slip planes (Forsberg and Locat, 2005;
Kvalstad et al., 2005a). Sandy contourites are even less cohesive and
are susceptible to liquefy under dynamic loading (earthquakes). To
date, no liquefaction potential on a large-scale has been observed in
the Storegga Slide area (Leynaud et al., 2004), suggesting that
liquefaction was not the decisive factor to generate sliding in this
area.

3.1.2.4. Presence of ﬂuids and gas hydrate dissociation. Numerous
seabed and subsurface ﬂuid escape features have been observed on
the southern Vøring Plateau and the northern Storegga slide
escarpment (Mienert et al.,1998; Bouriak et al., 2000; Gravdal et al.,
2003; Hovland et al., 2005). Note that the ﬂuid escape features are
a an indicator not only of existing overpressure but also of pressure
release! Additionally, extensive polygonal faulting, a non-tectonic
class of faults related to sediment contraction and ﬂuid expulsion,
has affected the underlying formation, and is thought to control
ﬂuid ﬂow on a regional scale (Bu¨ nz et al., 2003; Bryn et al., 2005a).
This may contribute ﬂuids to zones where gas hydrate form within
contouritic sediments. The role of free gas in the activation of
submarine slides was discussed by Best et al. (2003).
Gas hydrate stability highly depends on both temperature and
pressure (Fig. 4), parameters that have changed signiﬁcantly from
glacial to interglacial times (Mienert et al., 2005). Consequently,
such environmental changes may be responsible for the dissocia-
tion of oceanic gas hydrates, releasing vast volumes of over-
pressured gas and water in the conﬁned sediment’s pore space. This
would ultimately affect the stability of the host sediments of gas
hydrates (McIver, 1982; Kvenvolden, 1998). The effect environ-
mental changes have on hydrate stability is complex: during glacial
times, sea levels were typically several tens to up to 120 m lower
than today (Fairbanks, 1989; Fleming et al., 1998), which would
make hydrates less stable. However, during glacial times, the global
ocean conveyor belt weakens, resulting in cold bottom water
masses ﬂowing along the NE Atlantic continental margins (Dokken
and Jansen, 1999). This would make hydrates more stable during
glacial times. Consequently, one needs detailed information about
the time scales and amplitudes of both sea level change and bottom
water temperature ﬂuctuations before conclusions can be drawn
about the environmental control on hydrate stability. This means,
likewise, that the situation can be signiﬁcantly different from place
to place, especially in the high-latitude areas presently enjoying
warm water inﬂow.

Vogt and Jung (2002) and Mienert et al. (2005) propose a situ-
ation in which submarine slopes of the Norwegian margin receive
preconditions to slope failure due to methane hydrate dissociation.
Fig. 4 shows the hydrate stability in the pressure-temperature
domain. The initial rise in sea level after the LGM resulted in
favourable conditions for hydrate stability. Then, shortly after the
inﬂow of warmer bottom-water masses after the Younger Dryas
(12.7–11.5 ka), the temperature increase penetrated the seabed and
started affecting hydrates at their stability limit, despite the
ongoing
sea-level
rise
(pressure
increase).
From
theoretical

modelling, it appears that gas hydrate stability in shallow water
areas (typically less than 700–800 m) is primarily dominated by the
bottom-water temperature. The rapid rise of bottom-temperature
in early Holocene times due to the inﬂow of warmer water masses
then reduces hydrate stability (i.e. the stability limit shoals) on the
upper continental margin. Hydrate stability conditions in deeper
water areas where temperature ﬂuctuations are limited responds
predominantly to pressure changes under the inﬂuence of eustatic
sea level rise. This results in improved hydrate stability (i.e. the
stability limit subsides) on the lower continental margin. The
transition from the temperature-dominated area to the pressure-
dominated area lies in 600–800 m water depth (Mienert et al.,
2005). Modelling illustrated that the area of critical hydrate
stability changes along the mid-Norwegian margin correspond
remarkably well with the location of the Storegga Headwall, as
inferred from seismic reﬂection proﬁles (Mienert et al., 2005), and
hence, hydrate dissociation could precondition secondary slope
failures along the upper slope in the retrogressive slide develop-
ment of the Storegga landslide (McIver, 1982; Mienert et al., 2002;
Vogt and Jung, 2002; Mienert et al., 2005). Adding to the
complexity, Sultan et al. (2004b) propose that gas solubility
changes play a role in hydrate dissociation as well, at the top of the
gas hydrate stability zone, leading to gas hydrate melting and
potentially retrogressive failures.

3.1.2.5. Geomechanical properties of sediments
3.1.2.5.1. Triaxial compression test and sensitivity: contouritic and
glacigenic deposits. An analysis of the geomechanical or geotech-
nical properties of sediments is paramount in addressing the sed-
iment’s role in submarine failure (e.g. Locat et al., 2003a). For the
Trænadjupet slide (Fig. 5, Tables 2 and 3), Laberg et al. (2003) have
shown that two different types of sediments were observed in the
slide area, with strikingly different geomechanical properties:
glacigenic deposits and marine contouritic sediments. For the
Holocene Storegga Slide (Fig. 5, Tables 2 and 3) similar alternations
in sediment have been observed. Tjelta et al. (2002) have shown
that sediments in the slide area can be deﬁned in two main groups;
glacial and marine contouritic deposits (Table 3). Bryn et al. (2003)
consider a third one, the underlying ooze formation (Table 3) but
mentioned that the three main slip surfaces occurred in the
ﬁne-grained marine clay units (contourites). Haﬂidason et al.
(2003) illustrated that the glide planes in the Storegga slide area

were ﬁne-grained clayey sediments (geotechnically weak layers),
deposited during the interglacial periods.
In the following, the main geomechanical parameters associated
with contourites are presented (Table 3, Figs. 3, 6 and 7):

(1) Under triaxial compression tests on samples from the Træ-
nadjupet Slide area, the contourite drift sediments exhibit
a contractant behaviour resulting in the development of shear
bands (Laberg et al., 2003) which correspond to strain

Fig. 5. Location map of submarine mass movements (purple) observed on glaciated

database is used for bathymetry showing ocean basins in deep blue and shelf areas in

Fig. 6. Map showing the distribution of contourites on glaciated margins with main

concentration layers (Kimoto et al., 2004). However, we have to
keep in mind that dilatant–contractant behaviour depends on
the stress path. This behaviour is characteristic of low pre-
shear density and suggests that excess pore pressure genera-
tion could initiate shear bands and thus failure in the sediment.
This could be one of the main factors controlling the precon-
ditions for slope failure and the location of the slip planes. In
the Storegga Slide area, the ﬁne-grained contouritic marine
clays have also lower shear strength than the glacial clays
(Tjelta et al., 2002; Bryn et al., 2003) following the pattern
observed at Træandjupet.
(2) Also, the sensitivity of the soil (Table 3) should not be ignored.
Both for the Trænadjupet and the Storegga Slide areas, the
marine (contourite) clays exhibit the highest sensitivity,
parameter which lead to a more drastic decrease in shear
strength upon remoulding. Kvalstad et al. (2002) point to the
marine clay unit as the preferred lateral slip plane based on its
sensitivity (for the same consolidation stress) for the Storegga
slide.

Wilson et al. (2003) also concluded that the most likely ‘‘weak
layer’’ for the Afen slide (Fig. 1; Table 2) corresponds to a contourite
layer. Long et al. (2003) noticed that all submarine slides observed
in the Faeroe–Shetland Channel are associated with contouritic
sediments, characterized by a decrease in shear strength (and lower
remoulded strength) as seen previously, and a susceptibility to
liquefaction depending on the sand content.
The distribution of contourite drifts along glaciated continental
margins (Figs. 6 and 7) suggests that contourites are very often
associated with or at least found in the vicinity of major submarine
landslides (Bryn et al., 2005b). Furthermore, it appears that large
slides occurred where drifts were deposited on the upper part of
the continental slope (Fig. 7).
In the Storegga slide area, gas or gas hydrate has been identiﬁed
in weak, contouritic sediments (e.g. Bu¨ nz et al., 2003). The presence
of gas could further reduce the shearing resistance by creating
excess pore pressure.
3.1.2.5.2. Time-dependent viscoplastic deformation. Muir Wood
(1991; p. 421) shows a typical example of visco-plastic behaviour of
sediment for which the q/p0 ratio (q, deviator stress; p0 mean
effective stress; Fig. 8) controls the expansion (hardening; Fig. 8b)
or the contraction (softening; Fig. 8c) of the yield locus, which
corresponds to the onset of time-dependant viscoplastic defor-
mation. The generation of excess pore pressure in a fully consoli-
dated sediment does not modify the deviator stress but does
modify the mean effective stress (reduction) and thus is similar to
the viscoplastic stress change with a high q/p0 ratio (softening;
Fig. 8c).
Thus it is shown that excess pore pressure developing (e.g. due
to gas hydrate dissociation) or migrating laterally (pressure
gradient) in a fully consolidated sediment might trigger time-
dependent viscoplastic deformation leading to more favourable
conditions to failure after a speciﬁc time period. This might be the
case during lateral dissipation of excess pore pressure after a high
sedimentation rate period (Leynaud et al., 2007). However, such
conditions are not enough to trigger a slide on a 1 slope.
3.1.2.5.3. Strain softening. According to Andresen (2002), the
effect of strain softening associated with Norwegian marine clay on
submarine slope stability is more important that previously
thought. Kvalstad et al. (2002) modelled undrained progressive
failure at Ormen Lange within the Storegga Slide complex (100 m

Fig. 8. Sketch showing (a) elastic deformation inside static yield locus, (b) visco-plastic
deformation with yield locus expansion (low q/p0 ratio), (c) visco-plastic deformation
with yield locus contraction (high q/p0 ratio), adapted from Muir Wood, 1991. Red
arrows show the effect of excess pore pressure on p0 (no effect on q) which means that
visco-plastic deformation may occur with only excess pore pressure developing in
sediment: (1) a reduction of EPP controls the increase of p0 (similar to A–C) and thus
the yield locus expands and the soil hardens; (2) an increase of EPP controls the
decrease of p0 (similar to A–D) leading to yield locus contraction and deformation
accelerates to failure.

high headwall; 30 inclination), through ﬁnite element analyses
using a non-linear strain softening material for the basal layer. They
obtain a decrease in safety factor from 1.37 to 1.08 using a sensi-
tivity St ¼ 3:0; whereas a sensitivity value of St ¼ 5:0 leads to
a safety factor dropping below unity, hence implying failure. With
such behaviour, retrogressive failure could have developed and
forms a reasonable explanation for the slide mechanics and
development in agreement with geomorphological interpretations.
Obviously, a trigger is needed to initiate this process. The retro-
gressive slide model proposed by Kvalstad et al. (2002, 2005a,b)
requires the initial removal of sediment from the toe of the slope.
Undrained expansion of the soil resulting from pressure reduction
and strain concentrations leads to a process which maintains the
retrogressive failure development.
3.1.2.5.4. Creep. Creep, or secondary consolidation, corresponds
to slow deformations with time at constant effective stress after the
complete dissipation of excess pore pressure. Creep process occur
on both glaciated and non-glaciated margins. This deformation
results from the readjustment of particle contacts after the primary
consolidation (Muir Wood, 1991). The creep process is summarized
in Fig. 9 with the three different stages, with tertiary creep culmi-
nating in failure. Okamoto et al. (2004) identiﬁed two recent
landslides in Norway (in quick clay deposits) where secondary and
tertiary creep stages were observed before the failure.
3.1.2.5.5. Slope steepening. Slope stability also depends on the
dip angle as the downslope force increases with increasing dip.
However, in most cases, enormous slides occurred on gentle slopes
of less than 2 degrees (Hu¨hnerbach and Masson, 2004). This
suggests that, locally, slope angle does not signiﬁcantly inﬂuence the
occurrence of large-scale sliding on glaciated margins. On the other
hand, there is some evidence (Vorren et al., 1998) that small slides
between the Trænadjupet and Andøya Slides (Fig.1) are more likely
to occur along the steepest part of the continental margin. Nielsen
and van Weering (1998) also concluded that instability along the
northeastern Faeroes margin might be triggered by rapid steepening
of the slope angle. Finally, Wilson et al. (2003) mention that a slope
angle is not sufﬁcient as parameter to explain the Afen slide, since
the surrounding area appears stable despite the higher slope angles.
3.2. Non-glaciated margins

Submarine slides, debris ﬂows and megaturbidites on the non-
glaciated margin of Europe (south of 52N) are listed in Table 4 (see
also Fig. 1). Here, we concentrate on the submarine mass
movements on the Iberian and Mediterranean margins (Fig. 1).

3.2.1. Triggering mechanisms: Seismic activity and seismic loading
Earthquakes resulting from the collision between the African
and Eurasian plates are distributed in a several hundreds of km

3.2.2. Preconditions to failure
3.2.2.1. Slope steepening and salt tectonics. Three different param-
eters have to be considered here: (1) the tectonic-induced over-
steepening due to extensional faults of the shelf/slope, (2) high
mean slope angles, and (3) salt tectonics. Faults induced by
tectonics can play a role as a trigger mechanism as proposed by
Reeder et al. (2000) for the Herodotus Basin mega-turbidite. The
second parameter is the average continental slope angle, for
example on the Libyan/Egyptian continental margin. There, the
continental slope is typically much steeper (upper slope: 3.7,
lower slope; 6.0) compared to glaciated margins. The third
parameter, salt tectonics, is particularly relevant for the Iberian,
Fig. 9. Schematic diagram showing the different stages of the creep process. From
Okamoto et al. (2004). The failure occurs at the end of the tertiary creep.

wide belt in which concentrated bands of high seismic activity
occur (Jackson and England, 1992). The most active area in terms of
seismicity is the Mediterranean Sea (Fig. 1: Iberia, Greece; Turkey,
e.g. Gaullier et al., 2004), and as such seismicity cannot be over-
looked as a potential triggering mechanism for submarine slope
failure in this region. Lebreiro et al. (1997) showed that the 1755
Lisbon earthquake (M > 8.5) triggered the most recent episode of
turbidite currents which resulted in a thin turbidite deposit in the
Horseshoe Abyssal Plain. This area is a high seismic active area
related to the Eurasian–African plate compressional zone off the
Iberian Peninsula (Gutscher, 2004). On the marginal slopes of the
eastern Mediterranean Seas, Lykoussis et al. (2003) observed that
slope instabilities could be induced by ground acceleration. This is
also a plausible triggering mechanism for slides on the eastern
Tyrrhenian margin (e.g. Licosa and Paola Slides) (Trincardi et al.,
2003). Perissoratis and Papadopoulos (1999) report that a large
mass movement in the southwestern part of the Amorgos basin
(south of the Aegean sea) has been triggered by one (or both) July
1956 seismic events (M ¼ 7:5 main shock and M ¼ 7:2 aftershock,
13 min later), with the epicentre located in the immediate vicinity
of the headwall scarp (less than 10 km off target). However,
submarine mass movements are generally of signiﬁcantly smaller
size when compared to the glaciated margin (Tables 2 and 4).

3.2.1.1. Volcanic activity. The main scar of the Big ’95 submarine
slide in the Mediterranean Sea (Fig. 1; 29a, 0E–40N) is related to
a crest of a deep-seated volcanic dome, suggesting that volcanic
activity (Columbretes volcanic ﬁeld) lies at the origin of the slide
(Urgeles et al., 2005). However, volcanic activity ceased at approx.
0.3 Ma, which suggests that the timing of the dome development
and submarine slide (Table 2, 11 ka) are not related. Thus, the
triggering process could be more complex. Here, a combination of
trigger and pre-conditioning factors may have promoted instability
of the slope, which includes oversteepening, reduction of shear
strength along the fault plane, and differential compaction and
faulting associated with a deep-rooted inactive volcanic dome.
Trincardi and Argnani (1990) also mention that an intense volca-
notectonic
activity as
triggering
mechanism
combined
with
a decollement surface (precondition to failure) could explain the
observed Gela Slide (Table 2, Fig. 1).

3.2.1.2. Anthropogenic activities. Unlike the other areas and slope
failures mentioned in this overview paper so far, the Mediterranean
provides a good example for human-induced submarine slope
failures. The Nice airport slide occurred in 1979, where the thickest
part of the failed sediments coincided with the harbour extension
(Cochonat et al., 1993; Sultan et al., 2004a; Dan et al., 2007).
Embankment increased the loading on shallower as well as deeper
sediments leading to the failure with (decreasing soil resistance) or
without (increasing loading) excess pore pressure development. It
is noteworthy that anthropogenic activities along fjords have also
resulted in slope failures (Locat et al., 2003b; Longva et al., 2003)
and therefore endangering the local population.

halokinetic processes also cause oversteepening of ﬂanks in deep-

A comparison between continental slope proﬁles for high
(Storegga Slide), medium (Armorican margin) and low (NW-

margins seem to be more gentle (below 2) than on non-glaciated
margins (greater than 2). As the largest submarine landslides are
found on the glaciated margins, the dip angle of the slope is
certainly not the prior parameter governing slope failure in this

3.2.2.2. Presence of ﬂuids and gas hydrate dissociation. Reeder et al.
(2000) take into account that gas hydrate dissociation could have
triggered the Herodotus megaturbidite based on the relatively low
sea-level (75 m to 120 m) and thus the lower hydrostatic pres-
sure at the time of the event (27.1 ka). However, there is no direct or
indirect evidence of gas hydrates along the continental slope of the
eastern Mediterranean Sea (Rothwell et al., 2000). Despite this, gas-
bearing sediments with supposedly higher porosities are found in
the shallower part of the Gulf of Cadiz (Baraza and Ercilla, 1996), an
area where contouritic sediments have accumulated. High perme-
ability for silty-sandy sediments will allow gas to migrate easily

through the subsurface, and eventually escape at the seabed. Low
permeability sediments, like clayey beds, often act as permeability
barriers preventing ﬂuid migration. Over time, this will however
lead to the build-up of excess pore pressure beneath those
permeability traps within the slope sediments and hence a situa-
tion prone for failure to occur.
Locally, gas hydrates exist in the Mediterranean deep waters
(Lykoussis et al., 2003) as well as in the Gulf of Cadiz (e.g. Dı´az-del-
Rı´o et al., 2003) in ﬂuid escape structures, e.g. gas chimneys and
mud volcanoes. The accumulation of authigenic carbonates and
seep related chimneys indicate a long term existence. Pockmarks
are often found in the immediate vicinity of slides or other mass
wasting processes in the western Mediterranean, the Gulf of Cadiz
and other places. Typically, they are found upslope of the slides in
undisturbed sediments being indicators of ﬂuid escape from
possibly overpressurized ﬂuids (e.g. Baraza et al., 1992; Baraza and
Ercilla, 1996).

3.2.2.3. High sedimentation rates and sea level changes. In contrast
to the formerly glaciated NE Atlantic margin, the shelf of the
Mediterranean Seas is relatively narrow. Only at the mouths of
large rivers, well-deﬁned seaward prograding deltas have devel-
oped. The most important ones are the Ebro, Rhone, Po and Nile
deltas where sedimentation rates are typically high to very high
with 10 cm/yr (100 m/kyr; Ambla`s et al., 2004). Average sedimen-
tation rates around 2 m/kyr have been estimated on the upper
slope in the Gulf of Lion (between 26 ka and 15 ka, Berne´ et al.,
2004) but ‘‘instantaneous’’ rates can reach 1 m/yr in prodeltaic
settings. According to Dubar and Anthony (1995) and L’homer
(1980), an average sedimentation rate was estimated around
8 m/kyr between w12 ka and w7 ka (rapid sea level rise) and
around 3.5 m/kyr between w7 ka and the present (slow sea level
rise) for the Var delta.
Low angle (1) clinoforms developed with high accumulation
rates of muddy sediments (Berne´ et al., 2004). However, during sea-
level lowstands large portions of the shelf areas were exposed, and
sediment transport from rivers reached the shelf edge and upper
slope resulting in sand deposition. Thus, during falling stages of sea
level (or low sea level), slope failures and increased canyon inci-
sions dominate with large portions of the sediments being trans-
ported to the deep basin (Berne´ et al., 2004).
4. Discussion

During the last 10–15 years, submarine mass movements and
their consequences were more and more recognized as an impor-
tant topic in continental margin research. In particular, the ques-
tions about where, when, and why submarine mass movements
occur are of prime interest (e.g. Locat and Mienert, 2003; Mienert,
2004) as well as the role of sea level changes driven by global
climate change (e.g. Maslin et al., 2004). Low sea levels invoke
changes in the local and global hydrodynamic regime and will affect
gas hydrate stability. On glaciated margins during glacial times, the
stability of submarine gas hydrates increased because cold bottom
water masses present on the upper slope offsets the effect of
pressure drop (Fig. 4). On non-glaciated margins, the stability of
submarine gas hydrates probably decreased because warm water
masses may prevail, while the pressure decreases (Maslin et al.,
2004). Melting of hydrates results in excess pore pressure devel-
opment, which is a key aspect for slope stability (Fig. 8).
On non-glaciated margins, most submarine slope failures
occurred between 45 ka and 16 ka (Maslin et al., 2004), which
correspond to a low sea level-period (Fig. 11). The frequency of
turbidites at those times was higher for the Horseshoe Abyssal
Plain (Lebreiro et al., 1997). Sediment destabilization is most likely
controlled by sediment supply, which in turn causes steeper slope

Fig. 11. Megaturbidites and submarine slides plotted versus sea level (adapted from
Reeder et al., 2000 and Maslin et al., 2004). The volume of mass movements is higher
during high sea level (70% volume during Holocene). The latter appears also
predominant on glaciated margin (80% volume (blue area) corresponding to events
occurring on glaciated margin).

angles. Periods of sea-level regression or transgression were
proposed by Weaver et al. (1992) to correlate with large-volume
turbidites rather than high or low sea-level stands. Marjanac, 1996
also suggested that the rate of sea level change could be the main
factor to explain mega-beds deposition. Trincardi et al. (2003)
speculate that two submarine slides on the Tyrrhenian margin
(Paola and Licosa Slides) occurred in response to the relative sea-
level rise or melt water pulse around 13.8 ka (20 m in 500 years).
They noticed that the Big ’95 submarine slide dated around 11.5 ka
also corresponds to a melt water pulse.
A rise in sea level is accompanied by changes in the hydrody-
namic and sedimentary regime. Vertical tectonic movements due
to the decay of ice sheets (rising sea level) cause an increase in
seismic activity on glaciated margins (Bungum et al., 2005). Thus,
times of intense isostatic rebound may invoke high magnitude
earthquakes on NE-Atlantic passive margins, similar in magnitude
to today’s active Mediterranean margins. Additionally, the upper
slopes of glaciated margins experience pronounced bottom water
temperature increases during glacial–interglacial transitions. As
such, they are more susceptible to hydrate melting, excess pore
pressure build up and therefore slope instability (Maslin et al.,
2004; Mienert et al., 2005). In contrast, non-glaciated margins were
continuously submerged by warmer waters and should have
experienced more stable gas hydrates due to sea level rise. The
most important triggering mechanisms for slope failures on both
glaciated and non-glaciated margins seem to be high magnitude
earthquakes.
Regarding the frequency of mass wasting events, the mega-
turbidites that occurred in the Mediterranean vary from one main
event during the past 120 kyr (Balearic Abyssal Plain) to one main
event during the past 60 kyr (Herodotus Basin). For the Agadir
Canyon system (Ercilla et al., 2003), one large turbidity current
feeds the Agadir Basin every 30 kyr (Weaver et al., 2000). When
compared with submarine slides on the formerly glaciated mid-
Norwegian margin where one mega-slide occurred approximately
every 100 kyr (Solheim et al., 2005a), the frequency of mega events
is higher on non-glaciated margins. However, the total volume of
mobilized sediments from mass wasting is much larger on the
glaciated margin (Maslin et al., 2004).

There is evidence that earthquakes with amplitudes similar to
active eastern Mediterranean margins seismicity concentrated on
formerly glaciated margins during peak deglaciation periods. In
addition, sedimentation rates on glaciated margins show high and
rapid depositions during glacial and deglaciation times. During
these times, the probability of excess pore pressure build up in
contourite sediments increased along the upper continental slopes.
Thus, both preconditioning factors and trigger mechanisms for
causing slope failures existed during a very speciﬁc time period, i.e.
the transition from glacial to interglacial time. In contrast, earth-
quakes on active subduction zones of the Mediterranean margins
can be considered to be frequent during both glacial and intergla-
cial time. Here, the frequency of sliding appears more determined
by preconditioning factors during glacial times. Rivers transported
sandy sediments directly to the shelf edge and upper slope creating
unstable slope conditions. The latter occurred during a low sea level
when erosion by rivers caused major canyon incisions and mass
movements on the upper slope as identiﬁed in the western Medi-
terranean (e.g. Droz et al., 2001).
5. Conclusions

According to the observations from glaciated and non-glaciated
margins, one can draw the following conclusions concerning
submarine slope instabilities.
(1) From to the observed mass wasting types, we propose to
split up the European continental margin in Glaciated (north of
52N; presence of the ice cap during glacial period) and Non-
Glaciated margin (south of 52N). Large-scale slides dominate
north of 62N whereas megaturbidites and debris ﬂows are mainly
observed south of 35N. A broad range of mass wasting processes
are observed in the Mediterranean sea whereas they are rather
scarce between 35N and 52N on the Atlantic margin.
(2) On glaciated margins (low slope angle), submarine slides are
closely related to the extent of ice sheets and the location of con-
tourites on continental slopes; north of 62N, mega-scale sliding is
preponderant during sea level rise from glacial to interglacial times
whereas on non-glaciated margins (high slope angle), mega-
turbidites and debris ﬂows occur predominantly during low sea
level when rivers transported their sediment load directly to the
shelf edge and coastal upwelling was limited to the upper slope.
This suggests a relationship between the type of instabilities and
the average slope angle of the continental margin; large-scale slides
associated with low slope angles and presence of the ice sheet (role
of excess pore pressure related to high sedimentation rates) while
megaturbidites and debris ﬂows are rather associated with high
slope angles and narrow shelf.
(3) On glaciated margins, a combination of preconditions to
failure exists during the Holocene such as excess pore pressure
generation (from rapid deposition) with slow dissipation or gas
hydrate dissociation. The ﬁnal triggering mechanisms are possibly
high-magnitude earthquakes between 10 ka and 8 ka due to
isostatic rebound during major ice sheet decay. Long-term insta-
bility observed in the vicinity of the Storegga Slide (Glaciated
margin) suggests a precondition to failure process related to
recurrent glacial–interglacial period cycles.
(4) Though the effect of excess pore pressure development on
shear strength and subsequently slope failure is still not well
understood, it appears that geotechnical properties of contourites
play a major role in the instability mechanism on glaciated margins.
Up until now, there is no sign of such inﬂuence of contourites on
non-glaciated margins.
(5) Non-glacigenic margins as presented experienced hal-
okinetic processes and oversteepening of slopes, creating areas
prone to failure. Trigger mechanisms of active Mediterranean
margins
appear
to
be
predominantly
earthquakes,
but

preconditions to failure exist at least for speciﬁc events, involving
human (Nice) or volcanic activity (Big ’95, Torreblanca).
